awd_abstract_narration:
People often respond emotionally to the dramatic socio-political events that are taking place around the word. This is especially true when such events are occurring in well-established democracies and at home, and not just in faraway countries. In many cases, expressing strong emotions can create and perpetuate conflicts with others who may be responding to these events in very different ways. Acknowledging the importance of emotions in intergroup conflicts has led to recent attempts to reduce conflict-related emotions using psychological interventions. Initial studies show that these efforts can be helpful in reducing destructive emotions and promoting conflict resolution. However, it is not typically possible to apply interventions to an entire population. Instead, interventions must be applied to a portion or subgroup of the population. This project examines whether reducing a subgroup's emotions can have a long-lasting influence on the overall group's emotions and level of conflict. The goal of the project is to find ways to optimize psychological interventions and reduce harmful conflict.
 
Three studies use the Israeli-Palestinian conflict as a case study. The first study examines the unfolding of negative emotional dynamics within groups. Recent developments in computer science are utilized to create an online network that allows the examination of real-time, online interactions. The second study examines how these emotional dynamics are influenced by emotion regulation interventions applied to different portions of the group. This will enable the identification of the conditions under which interventions achieve maximum utility in influencing overall negative group emotions. The third study tests the long-term effects of the emotion regulation interventions and assesses how these effects are influenced by emotional dynamics. The research will make an important contribution to maximizing the scalability of psychological interventions and achieving the long-term aim of reducing harmful conflict.  Immediate applications resulting from the project can be facilitated by the Stanford Center for Social Psychological Answers to Real-World Questions (SPARQ), which provides consultation to many organizations interested in psychological interventions. A collaboration with researchers at the Interdisciplinary Center (IDC) in Herzliya, Israel provides additional opportunities for implementation and dissemination. The project includes the development of an open source platform that can be utilized by researchers in many fields, thereby advancing other areas of science.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Recognizing the importance of emotions in intergroup conflicts, researchers have begun to develop interventions that seek to help individuals reduce negative emotions in conflict situations. One particularly promising intervention is a reappraisal intervention – an emotion regulation strategy that involves changing how one thinks about a situation with the goal of influencing one’s emotional response. The advantage of reappraisal is that it is cheap, quick, and easy to explain, and it seems to consistently impact individuals emotions in a variety of contexts, including intergroup conflicts. However, reappraisal interventions – and other similar interventions in the context of intergroup conflict – are hindered by the fact that in most cases it is not feasible to intervene on the whole population.

This suggests a set of questions which have motivated the present work. In particular, the goal of the current project was to address three inter-related questions: First, can reappraisal work, even when other people around the target of intervention are not necessarily using reappraisal? Second, what is the relationship between the proportion of the group who go through the intervention and the intervention’s effectiveness, both on the targets of intervention as well as the untreated individuals in the group? It is possible, for example, that conducting an intervention for just a small portion of the population would lead to no effect or even a reverse effect (i.e., reactance) in the untreated population and would therefore be counterproductive. It is also possible that the impact on the untreated participants becomes stronger at a certain threshold. Third, if the intervention does spread, what is the mechanism for that spread? Answering these questions is crucial if we want to apply emotion regulation interventions on groups and populations and maximize its spread.

Using the Israeli-Palestinian conflict as a case study, we examined whether and in what way the proportion of participants that completed a reappraisal intervention within a small group led to a reduction in the groups’ emotions. This was done using a novel paradigm in which groups of six participants reacted to conflict-related stimuli in real time, while observing each other's reactions. Within these groups, we manipulated the proportion of participants who completed a reappraisal intervention before conducting our interactive task. We then examined how our intervention impacted both the treated and untreated participants' negative emotions, and how emotions were modified as a function of the proportion of treated participants within each group.

Our first finding was that our reappraisal manipulation was effective for the treated individuals, even when other people around the targets of the intervention are not using reappraisal. Our second finding was that the reappraisal manipulation spread from the treated individuals to the untreated individuals, and that this effect increased in magnitude as the proportion of treated individuals increases. Our third finding was that Semantic Projection Analysis of the text produced by our participants showed that the untreated participants adopted the reappraisal language more as the proportion of the treated participants increased, providing a potential mechanism for the effects described above.
